--- AI Assistant ---

Thanks for that information! I can see this is related to the SpamTag add-in for Outlook after your upgrade to MailEssentials 22.2.

Good news - I found some relevant information about this exact issue! There's actually a known problem with SpamTag connectivity after upgrading to version 22.x, and a patch has been released to address it.

Based on the knowledge base, here's what's happening and how to fix it:

Solution: Apply the MailEssentials 22.2 Patch

A new version with the fix has been released: MailEssentials 22.2 - patch

Here are the steps to resolve this:

Step 1: Upgrade to the Latest MailEssentials Version

  1. Follow the upgrade steps in this article: Upgrading to the latest version of MailEssentials
  2. Use the GFIMailEssentials.exe file for the upgrade

Step 2: Uninstall and Reinstall SpamTag

  1. Open Add/Remove Programs in Windows and uninstall GFI MailEssentials SpamTag
  2. Delete residual files:
    • Delete the folder ...\\GFI\\MailEssentials SpamTag\\
    • Browse to ...\\Users\\Default\\AppData\\Local\\GFI\\ and delete the GFI MailEssentials folder
  3. Temporarily disable UAC (User Access Control):
    • Go to Start > Control Panel > User accounts > Change User Account Control Settings
    • Set to Never Notify
  4. Reinstall SpamTag from the updated MailEssentials installation

Before we proceed, let me ask a couple of quick questions to make sure we're on the right track:

  1. Have you already applied the 22.2 patch, or are you still on the initial 22.2 release?
  2. Are all users experiencing this issue, or just specific ones?

--- Customer (Mike Willard) ---

Where do I get the fixed spamtag installer?


--- AI Assistant ---

Great question! The SpamTag installer is actually included with the main MailEssentials installation package.

Here's how to get it:

Getting the Fixed SpamTag Installer

  1. Download the latest MailEssentials 22.2 patch from your GFI Accounts Portal:

    • Log in to your account at the GFI Accounts Portal
    • Navigate to your MailEssentials product
    • Download the latest GFIMailEssentials.exe installer

  2. Extract SpamTag from the installer:

    • Once you have the GFIMailEssentials.exe file, you can extract the SpamTag installer from it
    • The SpamTag installer (SpamTagSetup.exe or similar) should be located within the installation package

  3. Alternative - Install from the MailEssentials Server:

    • After upgrading MailEssentials on your server, the updated SpamTag installer is typically located in the MailEssentials installation directory
    • Default path is usually: C:\Program Files\GFI\MailEssentials\SpamTag\ or similar
    • Look for the SpamTag setup/installer file there

Quick clarification: Have you already upgraded your MailEssentials server to the 22.2 patch version, or do you need to do that first?

This is important because you'll want to make sure the server is patched before reinstalling SpamTag on the client machines. 🔧

  1. Navigate to that folder on your MailEssentials server

Perfect! I found a specific article about this exact issue. This is a known problem with version 22.x upgrades. Let me walk you through the solution:

Solution for SpamTag Connection Issues After 22.x Upgrade

Based on the Spam Tag cannot connect after upgrading to version 22.x article, here's what you need to do:

Step 1: Complete Uninstall of Old SpamTag

Before reinstalling, you need to completely remove the old SpamTag configuration:

  1. Uninstall the current SpamTag from the client machine (Control Panel > Programs and Features)
  2. Close Outlook completely
  3. Delete the old configuration folder:
    • Navigate to: C:\Users\Default\AppData\Local\GFI\
    • Delete the GFI MailEssentials folder
  4. Restart the client machine (recommended)

Step 2: Reinstall SpamTag

  1. Copy the GFIMailEssentialsSpamTag.exe from the server's \Outlook\ folder
  2. Right-click and select Run as administrator
  3. Enter the correct MailEssentials URL (e.g., http:///MailEssentials)
  4. Wait for the installer to verify the connection

Step 3: Verify Connection

After installation:

  • Open Outlook
  • Check if the SpamTag toolbar appears in the Home ribbon
  • The Spam/Not Spam buttons should NOT be greyed out
  • Click Settings to verify the server URL and credentials
  • Clicking OK should not show any authentication errors

Have you tried completely removing the old configuration folder before reinstalling? This step is critical for version 22.x upgrades. Let me know if you need help with any of these steps! 🔧

--- Customer (Mike Willard) ---

--- AI Assistant ---

Hmm, that's frustrating - you've done all the right steps so far. Let me dig a bit deeper into this connection issue.


--- AI Assistant ---

Perfect! I found a specific article that addresses exactly this error. There's a known issue with the SpamTag installer failing to verify the URL even when the server is reachable.

Here's what we need to check and try:

Troubleshooting Steps:

1. Check the Exact URL Format
When you're entering the URL in the installer, what format are you using? It should be:

  • http://servername or http://servername:port (if using a custom port)
  • https://servername or https://servername:port (if using SSL)

Important: Don't include any trailing slashes or additional paths.

2. SSL Certificate Issue (if using HTTPS)
If you're trying to use HTTPS, the installer requires a valid HTTPS certificate. If you're using a self-signed certificate or there are certificate issues, this will cause the verification to fail.

3. Check the Installer Log
The installer creates a detailed log that can tell us exactly what's failing. Can you check this log file?

  • Location: %temp%\gfioutlookinstall_DATE.log
  • To get there quickly: Press Windows Key + R, type %temp% and press Enter
  • Look for the most recent gfioutlookinstall_*.log file

A few quick questions:

  1. What exact URL are you entering in the installer? (e.g., http://mailserver or https://mail.domain.com)
  2. Are you using a custom port for MailEssentials?
  3. If using HTTPS, do you have a valid SSL certificate installed (not self-signed)?
  4. Can you open the installer log and share any error messages you see?

The full article with more details is here: Error: 'The installer failed to verify the URL' When Installing Spamtag

Let me know what you find, and we'll get this sorted out! 🔍

--- AI Assistant ---

Perfect! Now I can see exactly what's happening. The log reveals the real issue:

The Problem:
The installer is trying to reach http://exch2019_services/clientaccessversionservice.svc (notice the underscore and "_services" suffix), but it cannot resolve that hostname. The error says: The remote name could not be resolved: 'exch2019_services'

This is a DNS/hostname resolution issue. The installer is appending "_services" to your server name, but that hostname doesn't exist in DNS or the hosts file.

Here's what we need to do:


--- AI Assistant ---

Excellent! Now I understand the issue better. The installer is trying to construct a service endpoint URL and needs proper DNS resolution. Here's what we need to fix:

Solution: Add DNS/Hosts File Entry

The installer is automatically appending "_services" to your server name to reach the web service endpoint. Since exch2019_services cannot be resolved, we need to create that hostname mapping.

Option 1: Add to Windows Hosts File (Quick Fix)

  1. Open Notepad as Administrator

    • Press Windows Key, type "Notepad"
    • Right-click on Notepad and select "Run as administrator"

  2. Open the hosts file

    • In Notepad, go to File → Open
    • Navigate to: C:\Windows\System32\drivers\etc
    • Change the file type dropdown from "Text Documents" to "All Files"
    • Open the file named hosts

  3. Add this entry (replace the IP with your actual Exchange server IP):

        exch2019_services

    For example, if your Exchange server IP is 192.168.1.10:

    192.168.1.10    exch2019_services

  4. Save the file and close Notepad

Option 2: Add DNS Record (Better for Multiple Users)

If you have multiple users who need SpamTag, it's better to add a DNS A record or CNAME:

  • Create a DNS A record: exch2019_services → pointing to your Exchange server IP
  • OR create a CNAME: exch2019_services → pointing to exch2019

After making the DNS/hosts change:

  1. Test the resolution - Open Command Prompt and run:

    ping exch2019_services

    It should resolve to your Exchange server IP

  2. Try the SpamTag installer again using http://exch2019 as the URL

Quick questions:

  • What's the IP address of your Exchange server (exch2019)?
  • Are you installing this for just one user or multiple users across your organization?

Let me know once you've added the hosts entry and we'll test the installer again! 🔧

    • Click "Enable"

--- Customer (Mike Willard) ---

there is no *.svc


--- AI Assistant ---

Aha! That's a critical finding. The .svc handler is missing, which means IIS cannot process WCF service files. This is why you're getting the 403 error.

The .svc files are WCF (Windows Communication Foundation) services that MailEssentials uses, and without the proper handler, IIS doesn't know how to serve them.

Let's fix this by registering the .NET Framework with IIS:

Option 1: Using aspnet_regiis (Recommended)

  1. Open Command Prompt as Administrator

  2. Run this command (for .NET 4.x):

    C:\Windows\Microsoft.NET\Framework64\v4.0.30319\aspnet_regiis.exe -i

  3. Wait for it to complete, then restart IIS:

    iisreset

Option 2: Manually add the .svc handler

If Option 1 doesn't work, we can manually add it:

  1. In IIS Manager, select MailEssentials
  2. Double-click Handler Mappings
  3. Click Add Managed Handler (on the right)
  4. Enter:
    • Request path: *.svc
    • Type: System.ServiceModel.Activation.ServiceHttpHandlerFactory, System.ServiceModel.Activation, Version=4.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=31bf3856ad364e35
    • Name: svc-Integrated-4.0
  5. Click OK

After either option, test again:

  • Try accessing http://exch2019_services/clientaccessversionservice.svc in your browser

Which option would you like to try first? 🔧

--- AI Assistant ---

No problem! Let's use the command-line approach instead, which is actually more reliable.

Let's register .NET with IIS using aspnet_regiis:

  1. Open Command Prompt as Administrator:

    • Press Windows Key
    • Type cmd
    • Right-click "Command Prompt"
    • Select "Run as administrator"

  2. Run this command:

    C:\Windows\Microsoft.NET\Framework64\v4.0.30319\aspnet_regiis.exe -iru

    (The -iru parameter installs ASP.NET and registers the script maps without affecting existing applications)

  3. Wait for it to complete (should take 30-60 seconds)

  4. Then restart IIS:

    iisreset

  5. After the restart, go back to IIS Manager:

    • Refresh the Handler Mappings for MailEssentials
    • Do you now see a handler for *.svc?

  6. Test the service endpoint again:

    • Open browser: http://exch2019/MailEssentials/clientaccessversionservice.svc
    • What do you see now?

Let me know what happens after running these commands! This should register all the necessary handlers for WCF services. 🔧

Ah, you're on Windows Server 2016 or newer! The aspnet_regiis tool doesn't work the same way on modern Windows versions. We need to ensure the proper Windows Features are enabled instead.

Let's check and enable the necessary IIS features:

  1. Open Server Manager

  2. Click Manage → Add Roles and Features

  3. Click Next until you reach Server Roles

  4. Expand Web Server (IIS) → Web Server → Application Development

  5. Make sure these are checked:

    • ✅ .NET Extensibility 4.7 (or 4.8)
    • ✅ ASP.NET 4.7 (or 4.8)
    • ✅ ISAPI Extensions
    • ✅ ISAPI Filters

  6. Also check under Management Tools:

    • ✅ IIS Management Console
    • ✅ IIS Management Scripts and Tools

  7. Click Next and Install

After installation completes:

  1. Restart IIS:

    iisreset

  2. Check Handler Mappings again in IIS Manager for the MailEssentials application

    • Do you now see handlers for *.svc?

  3. Test the service:

  • Browser: http://exch2019/MailEssentials/clientaccessversionservice.svc

Quick check before we proceed: What version of Windows Server are you running? (Server 2016, 2019, or 2022?) This will help me give you the exact feature names. 🔍

--- AI Assistant ---

Perfect! Windows Server 2022. Let's make sure the right features are enabled.

Check and enable the necessary IIS/.NET features:

  1. Open PowerShell as Administrator

  2. First, let's see what's currently installed:

    Get-WindowsFeature | Where-Object {$_.Name -like "*NET*" -or $_.Name -like "*WCF*"} | Select Name, InstallState

    Copy and paste the results here - this will show us what's missing

  3. Then run this command to install the necessary features:

    Install-WindowsFeature NET-Framework-45-Features, NET-Framework-45-Core, NET-Framework-45-ASPNET, NET-WCF-HTTP-Activation45, NET-WCF-TCP-Activation45, Web-ISAPI-Ext, Web-ISAPI-Filter, Web-Asp-Net45, Web-Net-Ext45 -IncludeManagementTools

  4. After installation, restart IIS:

    iisreset

The key feature we need is NET-WCF-HTTP-Activation45 - this is what enables the .svc handlers for WCF services.

Once you've run these commands:

  • Go back to IIS Manager → MailEssentials → Handler Mappings
  • Look for *.svc handlers now
  • Test: http://exch2019/MailEssentials/clientaccessversionservice.svc

That's strange - you're clearly in an elevated PowerShell session (you're in C:\Windows\system32), but IIS is denying access. This suggests IIS might be trying to restart on a remote server rather than locally.

Restart-Service WAS -Force

  • A domain policy restriction
  • IIS is configured to manage a remote server

--- Customer (Mike Willard) ---

WARNING: Waiting for service 'World Wide Web Publishing Service (W3SVC)' to stop... over and over


--- AI Assistant ---

The W3SVC service is hanging and won't stop gracefully. Let's force it to stop:

Stop the hung service forcefully:

  1. Press Ctrl+C to cancel the current command

  2. Find the process ID:

    Get-Process -Name "w3wp" -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue | Stop-Process -Force

  3. Force stop the service using taskkill:

    taskkill /F /FI "SERVICES eq W3SVC"

  4. Then stop the services:

    Stop-Service W3SVC -Force -NoWait
Stop-Service WAS -Force -NoWait

  5. Wait 10 seconds, then start them:

    Start-Sleep -Seconds 10
Start-Service WAS
Start-Service W3SVC

If that still hangs, let's just skip the restart for now and focus on checking/installing the Windows Features first. The restart can wait.

Run this to check what's installed:

Get-WindowsFeature | Where-Object {$_.Name -like "*NET*" -or $_.Name -like "*WCF*"} | Select Name, InstallState

We need to see what features are missing before we can fix the .svc handler issue. What does this command show? 📋
